conbody.p: uses a dedicated LVM thin pool to store application data and snapshots of application data. The distributed file system (DFS) of each tenant application that serviced manages is stored in separate virtual devices in the thin pool. The initial size of each tenant device is copied from the base device, which is created during the initial startup of serviced.
conbody.note: The physical devices associated with the thin pool must be persistent. If removable or re-connectable storage such as a storage-area network based on iSCSI is used, then the Device-Mapper Multipath feature of RHEL/CentOS must be enabled.
conbody.p:
includes the serviced-storage utility for creating and managing its thin pool. The serviced-storage utility:
can use physical devices or partitions and LVM physical volumes to create a new LVM thin pool for tenant data
can add space to a tenant device at any time
can identify and clean up orphaned snapshots
For convenience, the serviced-storage utility is recommended for creating the Docker thin pool.
